item.title: Live Briefing: Sri Lanka Bombings Live Updates: Terrorist Group Is Identified, and Death Toll Rises
item.media:description: Relatives unloading the coffin on Monday of Sneha Savindi, 12, who was killed in a suicide bombing at St. Sebastian’s Church in Negombo.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: A militant Islamist organization was blamed for the Easter Sunday suicide attacks at churches and hotels, and the number killed was lifted significantly, to 290.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Sri Lanka Bomb Attacks Targeting Christians Kill Hundreds
item.media:description: Sri Lankan military officials standing guard at St. Anthony’s Shrine in Colombo on Sunday. The clock, top left, is stuck at 8:45 a.m., the time of the attack.
item.description: The bombings shattered the relative calm of the once war-ravaged island nation amid a rise of religious extremism in South Asia.
item.dc:creator: DHARISHA BASTIANS, JEFFREY GETTLEMAN and KAI SCHULTZ

item.title: Sri Lanka Photos: Grief and Questions After the Attacks
item.media:description: St. Anthony’s Shrine in Colombo, Sri Lanka, on Monday, the day after an explosion killed multiple people there.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: Images from the devastation of the Easter Sunday attacks and glimpses of how the country is starting to mourn.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: The Interpreter: Sri Lanka Blocks Social Media, Fearing More Violence
item.media:description: Sri Lankan soldiers secured the area around St. Anthony’s Shrine in Colombo after a blast on Sunday.
item.description: Sri Lankan officials have a troubled relationship with social media. They have seen firsthand how quickly online hate can turn into deadly violence.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER

item.title: For Palestinian Families, ‘No Light at the End of the Tunnel’
item.media:description: Dina Teeti with her father, Hasan, who together run a wedding-planning company in the West Bank city of Nablus.
item.media:credit: Corinna Kern for The New York Times
item.description: The re-election of Benjamin Netanyahu, shortly after he vowed to apply Israeli sovereignty over the West Bank, was the latest blow to Palestinian aspirations for a state.
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HALBFINGER and MIRIAM BERGER

item.title: Victims of Sri Lanka Attacks: Who They Were
item.media:description: Investigators at St. Sebastian’s Church in Negombo, Sri Lanka, on Monday.
item.description: The identities of the victims in the Sri Lanka bombings have started to emerge.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Ukraine Election: Volodymyr Zelensky, TV Comedian, Trounces President
item.media:description: Volodymyr Zelensky, center right, at his campaign headquarters in Kiev on Sunday.
item.description: Volodymyr Zelensky, an actor best known for playing a president on television, decisively won the race, with nearly all votes officially counted.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS and IULIIA MENDEL

item.title: Sri Lanka Blames Radical Islamist Group for Easter Bombings
item.media:description: St. Anthony’s Shrine in Colombo, Sri Lanka, on Monday. Hundreds were killed and hundreds more wounded in coordinated blasts at churches and hotels across the country on Easter Sunday.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: Officials said the coordinated assaults had been carried out by National Thowheeth Jama’ath. They are investigating whether the attackers had help from overseas.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER and SANDRA E. GARCIA

item.title: Iran’s Supreme Leader Replaces Head of Revolutionary Guards
item.media:description: Brig. Gen. Hossein Salami was named the head of the Revolutionary Guard Corps in Iran and promoted to major general.
item.description: The replacement came two weeks after President Trump designated the Revolutionary Guards as a foreign terrorist organization.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Sri Lanka, Ukraine, ‘Game of Thrones’: Your Monday Briefing
item.media:description: A funeral today for one of the victims of the attack at St. Sebastian’s Church in Negombo, Sri Lanka.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS STANFORD

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.media:description: St. Sebastian’s Church in Negombo, Sri Lanka, on Sunday after a bomb blast.
item.description: Let us help you start your day.
item.dc:creator: MELINA DELKIC and ANDREA KANNAPELL

item.title: Northern Ireland Police Release 2 Teenagers Arrested in Journalist’s Death
item.media:description: Police officers in Londonderry, Northern Ireland, on Saturday searching the ground ground near where Lyra McKee was shot and killed last week.
item.description: Two teenagers who were detained in the shooting death of a 29-year-old journalist in Northern Ireland were let go from police custody Sunday night without being charged.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Religious Minorities Across Asia Suffer Amid Surge in Sectarian Politics
item.media:description: The bombings of three churches in Sri Lanka on Easter Sunday highlighted the vulnerability of Christians in Asia.
item.description: The bombings of three churches in Sri Lanka highlighted the growing vulnerability of religious minorities across Asia, from Christians in Hindu-majority India to Muslims in Buddhist-majority Myanmar.
item.dc:creator: HANNAH BEECH, DHARISHA BASTIANS and KAI SCHULTZ
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: What We Know and Don’t Know About the Sri Lanka Bombings
item.media:description: Soldiers inspecting St. Sebastian’s Church, the site of the deadliest attack on Sunday, in Negombo, a city about 20 miles north of Colombo.
item.description: Coordinated attacks killed more than 290 people in churches, the largest targeted assault on South Asian Christians in recent memory.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Sri Lanka, India, Dreamliner: Your Monday Briefing
item.media:description: The roof was blown off St. Sebastian’s Church in Negombo, north of Colombo.
item.description: Coordinated suicide bombings strike Sri Lanka
item.dc:creator: ANDREA KANNAPELL

item.title: Ecuador Detains a Friend of Assange. Critics Say It’s Guilt by Association.
item.media:description: An anti-government protest in Quito that was prompted in part by Ecuador’s decision to no longer protect the WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange.
item.description: Internet and free speech activists have come out in defense of Ola Bini, a Swedish cybersecurity expert, saying there is no evidence yet of a crime.
item.dc:creator: JOSÉ MARÍA LEÓN CABRERA

item.title: For Sri Lanka, a Long History of Violence
item.media:description: The scene after a Tamil Tiger suicide bombing at a mosque in Godapitiya, Sri Lanka, in 2009.
item.description: The small island nation is famous for its beauty, but also for a brutal three-decade civil war and sectarian tensions that still simmer.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Sri Lanka Bombings: Footage From the Aftermath
item.description: At least eight bombing attacks struck at least three churches in Sri Lanka, along with three five-star hotels favored by foreigners, killing 290 people.

item.title: Images of the Destruction and Despair in Sri Lanka
item.media:description: St. Sebastian’s Church in Negombo, north of Colombo, after a string of explosions across the country on Sunday.
item.description: Images of the churches that were attacked showed smashed pews, broken statues and charred beams. Windows, floors and ceilings were blown out at the hotels.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Police Warned That Sri Lanka Churches Were Bombing Targets
item.media:description: Covered bodies and debris in St. Anthony’s Shrine in Colombo, Sri Lanka, after a string of explosions ripped through hotels and churches on Sunday.
item.media:credit: Ishara S. Kodikara/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Multiple explosions killed more than 200 people at churches and across the country. Thirteen people have been arrested.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: HELSINKI DISPATCH: Finland’s Hobbyhorse Girls, Once a Secret Society, Now Prance in Public
item.media:description: “The normal things, that normal girls like, they don’t feel like my things,” said Fanny Oikarinen, an 11-year-old hobbyhorse enthusiast.
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.description: For years, a subculture of teenage hobbyhorse enthusiasts flourished under the radar. Now the craze is a national export, and a celebration of girlhood.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY and DMITRY KOSTYUKOV

item.title: The Revolutionary Force Behind Sudan’s Protest Movement? Doctors
item.media:description: A doctor treating a protester during a rally outside army headquarters in Khartoum. Doctors have played a striking role in shaping Sudan’s democratic movement.
item.description: A prescription for change: When Omar Hassan al-Bashir came to power in 1989, doctors were among the first to resist. Three decades later, they are at the forefront of the movement that toppled him.
item.dc:creator: JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: After Notre-Dame Fire, ‘Yellow Vest’ Protesters Return to Streets
item.description: Thousands of marchers rallied across France, calling for President Emmanuel Macron to address inequality. For some, the large amount of money pledged to reconstruct the cathedral underscored the need for action.

item.title: ISIS, After Laying Groundwork, Gains Toehold in Congo
item.media:description: United Nations peacekeeping soldiers from Tanzania searching for Allied Democratic Forces rebels in the Democratic Republic of Congo in November. Evidence ties the rebel group to the Islamic State.
item.description: A recent assault on a military barracks was the first Congo attack claimed by the terror group. But there were earlier signs of an ISIS franchise in the region.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI

item.title: Barred From Rallying Near a Scorched Notre-Dame, ‘Yellow Vest’ Protesters March On
item.media:description: Riot police officer clashed with protesters in Paris on Saturday.
item.description: As billionaires’ donations to rebuild the cathedral renewed anger over inequality, the protests — now in their 23rd week — drew 7,000 in the French capital.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: In Egypt Referendum, Only the Turnout Seems in Doubt
item.media:description: Banners in Cairo urged people to vote. Sometimes, the message was explicit about which way.
item.description: The country began three days of voting on constitutional amendments that will effectively extend President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi’s hold on power until 2030.
item.dc:creator: VIVIAN YEE
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )

item.title: Notre-Dame: A Calamity Threatening to Be Repeated Across France
item.media:description: Paris was struck in its very heart as flames devoured the roof of the Notre-Dame cathedral on Monday.
item.description: France’s dazzling heritage in stone has proved both beautiful and burdensome for the state, and well beyond its means to maintain.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Israel’s Ultra-Orthodox Parties Embrace Technology and Emerge Stronger
item.media:description: Modiin Illit is an urban settlement in the occupied West Bank, inhabited by some 70,000 people, nearly all Ultra-Orthodox Haredi Jews.
item.media:credit: Dan Balilty for The New York Times
item.description: The rabbis’ instructions ruled the day in the country’s recent parliamentary elections. Now, the politicians are preparing for a clash over state and religion.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Australian Fights to Save Her Grandchildren From Syrian Refugee Camp
item.media:description: The al-Hawl refugee camp in Syria’s Kurdish northeast, where women and children from areas formerly controlled by the Islamic State are living.
item.description: Karen Nettleton spent the past five years searching for her grandchildren, whose father was an ISIS fighter. Now their fate has become a political football.
item.dc:creator: LIVIA ALBECK-RIPKA
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: North Korea Hits a Man With Glasses
item.media:description: North Korea denounced President Trump’s national security adviser, John Bolton, as “dim-sighted” on Saturday.
item.description: A senior North Korean official dismissed President Trump’s national security adviser, John Bolton, as “dim-sighted” after he demanded more evidence of willingness to give up nuclear weapons.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Mexican Town Once Welcomed Migrants. Now It Blames Mexico’s President for Them.
item.media:description: Members of a migrant caravan made up mostly of Hondurans and Cubans resting on Thursday in the town plaza of Escuintla, Chiapas, Mexico.
item.media:credit: Brett Gundlock for The New York Times
item.description: A relentless series of migrant caravans in recent months has taxed local resources and the patience of residents who are turning their ire on the president.
item.dc:creator: PAULINA VILLEGAS and KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: He Stopped a Global Cyberattack. Now He’s Pleading Guilty to Writing Malware.
item.media:description: Marcus Hutchins, right, a British security researcher, at the Federal Courthouse in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, in 2017. He was arrested at the airport in Las Vegas earlier that year.
item.description: Marcus Hutchins, a British security researcher credited with halting a huge outbreak of ransom software in 2017, accepted United States charges over previous activity.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Kosovo Flies Home Jihadists’ Families From Syria
item.media:description: Kosovar children who were repatriated from Syria played in the compound of a detention center in the village of Vranidoll on Sunday.
item.description: Dozens of women and children, the relatives of Kosovo jihadists in Syria, and four suspected fighters were repatriated plane on Saturday under heavy security.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: India’s Chief Justice Is Accused of Sexual Harassment
item.media:description: Chief Justice Ranjan Gogoi of India’s Supreme Court at his swearing-in ceremony in October. He has denied sexually harassing a former assistant.
item.description: A former assistant said Chief Justice Ranjan Gogoi subjected her to unwanted touching, and that her family was singled out for retribution after she rebuffed him.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: Ukraine Election: Comedian Dismissed by President Is Favored to Get Last Laugh
item.media:description: The popularity of Volodymyr Zelensky, seen in a poster in Kryvyi Rih, Ukraine, has stunned the country’s establishment.
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.description: Volodomyr Zelensky is blessed with the talents that seem to count in politics now: a flair for grabbing attention with little concern for the details.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: India Elections 2019: Farmers Are Hurting and Millions Are Voting
item.media:description: An onion market in Lasalgaon, near Nashik, India.
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.description: The ruling B.J.P. party has not yet delivered the “good days” it promised to farm voters, who make up half of the electorate. In debt and despair, some wonder if anyone can.
item.dc:creator: VINDU GOEL and HARI KUMAR

item.title: Amid a Cyclone’s Floods and Destruction, Mozambique Finds Shards of Hope
item.media:description: A camp in Nhamatanda, Mozambique, serves people displaced by Cyclone Idai.
item.description: Our correspondent found both sorrow and resilience in one of the poorest corners of the planet after a savage storm left tens of thousands homeless.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH

item.title: India’s Elections Last For 39 Days. Here’s Why.
item.description: India’s election is the largest in the world. With roughly 900 million eligible voters, polling is a challenge. Our animated video explains how the government pulls it off.

item.title: After the Storm, a Fight for Survival in Mozambique
item.description: Idai was the deadliest cyclone to hit southern Africa in over a century. Augusto Brás and his wife, Amélia, lost their home and their son in the flooding. Now, with their crops ruined and the next big harvest a year away, staying alive is a daily struggle.

item.title: 2 Men Arrested in Killing of Lyra McKee, Northern Ireland Journalist
item.media:description: Police officers at the scene of Lyra McKee’s shooting in Londonderry, Northern Ireland, on Saturday.
item.description: The police in Northern Ireland said they had arrested two men in connection with journalist’s shooting, during a night of unrest in Londonderry.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: A Guide to Our Notre-Dame Fire Coverage
item.media:description: Notre-Dame cathedral at sunrise the day after the fire.
item.description: A look at a blaze that ravaged a symbol of Paris, prompted calls for people to unite in restoring it and spurred inquiries into how such a catastrophe could have been prevented.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINE HAUSER

item.title: Mueller Report, Notre-Dame, Royal Baby: Your Friday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: MELINA DELKIC and MARCUS PAYADUE

item.title: Notre-Dame’s Safety Planners Underestimated the Risk, With Devastating Results
item.media:description: Notre Dame Cathedral burning in Paris on Monday.
item.description: The man who oversaw the design of the fire safety system at the cathedral said he was “stunned” at the fire’s speed. Experts said the system included delays that cost firefighters critical minutes.
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD and JAMES GLANZ

item.title: The Mueller Report Has Finally Arrived. Ask Us About Our Coverage.
item.description: We’ve spent nearly three years covering the Mueller investigation and the Trump-Russia ties. What would you like to know about the back story?
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Trump Endorses an Aspiring Libyan Strongman, Reversing Policy
item.media:description: Khalifa Hifter, center, at a military parade in Benghazi last year.
item.description: The United States had condemned the Libyan militia leader Khalifa Hifter for trying to depose a U.N.-backed government. Now President Trump has backed him.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )

item.title: Mueller Report Likely to Renew Scrutiny of Steele Dossier
item.media:description: The London offices of Orbis Business Intelligence. The firm’s co-owner is Christopher Steele, who wrote a series of memos in 2016 alleging ties between the Trump campaign and the Kremlin.
item.description: The special counsel revealed that some claims in the dossier appeared to be false while others were impossible to prove. Republicans have vowed to investigate.
item.dc:creator: SCOTT SHANE, ADAM GOLDMAN and MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: ISIS Claims First Attack in the Democratic Republic of Congo
item.media:description: A health worker at an Ebola treatment center in Beni, Democratic Republic of Congo.
item.description: Islamic State propagandists said the group was responsible for an assault that left eight Congolese soldiers dead. It was the group’s first Congo attack.
item.dc:creator: STEVE WEMBI and JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: South African Church Wall Caves In, Killing at Least 13
item.description: The collapse at the start of the Easter weekend came during a storm that caused flooding and power outages, and ripped the roofs off buildings.
item.dc:creator: KIMON de GREEF
